column5: May 2004. Notes recovered from a recently unearthed old notebook. This brewery had quality control issues from the outset and only lasted a few months. Norwich City made up for the mistake by winning their game 1-0! Clear caramel golden color with almost no head. Caramel malty aroma with a low intensity. Medium light body and a soft to flat carbonation level. Tad sweet and almost no bitterness. Way out of balance. Caramel malt

column3: United States;Blonde Ale / Golden Ale;Keegan Ales;This was poured into a pint glass. The appearance was a nice looking hazy bronzed yellow to orange color. A decent transparency runs about. Carbonation runs upward at a moderate pace. A slim fingered foamy head sits for about a minute before dissipating adequately. The smell starts off with sweet apricot and a mildly sweet lemon combines over some light malt. There’s a light crisp refreshing grassiness there as well. The taste is mainly sweet through the fruity notes mentioned earlier. Light grassy hops balance in a slight bitter fashion. The light apricots come back in the aftertaste and leave a grassy finish. On the palate
column4: this one sat about a light on the body with a nice sessionable aspect to it. Carbonation runs fairly light on the tongue and leaves a semi-crisp yet smooth malty feature running over my tongue. Overall
column5: for a blonde/golden ale
column6: this is definitely one of the better ones on the market. Definitely makes the haters of the style reconsider their thoughts on the style.

column3: United States;Witbier / Belgian White Ale;Lake Placid Pub & Brewery;En fût. Pinte dégustée à la brasserie. Arôme: Odeur d’agrumes et d’épices. Apparence: La couleur est paille légèrement voilée avec une faible densité de bulle. Présence d’un mince col mousseux et d’une fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût d’agrumes et d’épices avec une pointe de banane. Durée moyenne de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement huileuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. L’arrière goût est légèrement citronné. (Rating #1058)

column17: medium bitter hops and grass. Body: Close to medium body. Slick and smooth palate. Mouth Feel: Strong lager maltyness in a lean but solid background. Pretty silky with every sip. The malt has that nice orangey taste which is a lot more natural and tastier than those by Suntory’s Premium Malt series. Lively lemon and grassy hop profile thanks to Burtonization (that sulphur aroma!). Sweetness is strong but very nice and tasty. The 6% booze is invisible. Excellent! Hoppiness: Strong lemon flesh and peels

United States;Stout - Imperial;Firehouse Brewing Company (SD);Very dark beer with no head. The bartender said this was his favorite and it appeared as if the waitresses liked it too as they kept pouring small glasses of it out of the tap and drinking it themselves. I believe it is one of their brewmasters specialties and will rarely be available. The bartender also said it was pretty strong in alcohol content as well. My roommate and I tried all six beers they had on tap and I woke up the next morning puking sick with hives
column4: so maybe I am allergic to some of the hops or barley in one of their beers. But in their defense the beers were mighty tasty especially the Brown Cow Ale.

column3: Germany;Märzen / Oktoberfest Bier;Brauerei Hacklberg;Bottle courtesy of Mario D. Il gusto al naso va verso il fruttato. L’intensità olfattiva è normale e la persistenza olfattiva è sufficiente. Il cappello è di schiuma compatta
column4: abbondante
column5: cremosa e dal colore bianco candido. Le bollicine sono grandi. La carbonazione è abbondante. La consistenza del liquido è limpida. Il perlage è costituito da bollicine fini
column6: con ascesa costituita da carbonazione media. Il colore è giallo dorato brillante. Il corpo è rotondo. Il dolce è medio e l’amaro è medio: non si surclassano. L’intensità gustativa è normale e la persistenza gustativa è sufficiente. Il gusto è piacevole. Le sensazioni boccali finali sono di facile beva. Il finale è dissetante e semplice. Il retrogusto è di media intensità. Sulla lingua si depositano sensazioni di cereali.

column3: United States;Specialty Grain - Other;Otto's Pub and Brewery;Transfer from BA review on 3-12-13- Served on hand pump in a pint glass Appearance – Served a hazy orange color with a one half finger just off white head. The head fades very rapidly leaving a decent level of lace on the sides of the glass. Smell- The aroma is mainly of a rye and bready nature mixed with grapefruit hop. Lingering with these aromas is a very light tangerine and a small amount of floral hop and almost spicy aroma. Taste – The flavor begins mainly of a bready and moderate rye flavor. These more malty flavors create a base for the brew and remain relatively constant throughout the taste. Upfront the taste is rather dry with a moderate grapefruit hop taste at the start. As the flavor advances the grapefruit hop grows stronger in nature and is joined by a lighter tangerine flavor that brings a light sweetness to the beer. The grapefruit hop maximizes more toward the middle of the taste and remains strong till the end. The tangerine fades a bit however and is replaced by a caramel sweetness more toward the end. Along with the transitions of the lighter sweet flavors
column4: a pine hop and lightly spiced flavor comes to the tongue at the end of the taste
column5: with the combination of flavors leaving a bready and rather bitter grapefruit hop flavor on the tongue. Mouthfeel – The body of the beer is on the thicker and chewier side with a carbonation level (as would be expected for a hand pump brew) that is a bit on the lower side. The thicker body and lower carbonation suit the hoppier flavor as well as rye quite nicely really giving those flavors a chance to be appropriately sensed by the tongue. Overall – A pretty nice Rye PA. A little dry and quite grapefruit hop heavy (possibly a bit more pine or earth would helped level it a bit more) but rather flavorful and quite nicely drinkable. Not bad and one to try if you have the chance.

column3: Germany;Porter - Baltic;Klosterbrauerei Neuzelle;As Refugium Männerstolz at 7.1% ABV. Pours opaque deep brown with ruby highlights. Moderate off-white head. Low retention. Thin lacing. Dark malts on aroma. Caramel. Roast. Coffee. Chocolate. Esters and phenols stay far away (moving closer as the beer gets warmer). Bit vinous. The same picture while tasting. Light to medium body. Oily. Low to light bitterness. The review seems to be positive as I read it again. In fact this brew lacks power and smoothness that are IMO appropriate with Baltic porters.

column1: Flossmoor Station Break the Curse Weizen Bock;Flossmoor
column3: United States;Bock - Weizenbock;Flossmoor Station Restaurant & Brewery;Wow. This is an amazing Weizen Bock. It's got everything that a good hefeweizen and then doubled. There's more banana (but not overripe or out of control). There's more clove (but not overwhelming). There's most wheat flavor. There's more creaminess in the body. It even manages to retain some of the refreshing citrus qualities and even manages to keep a little lightness compared to its size that make this a surprising beer.

column2: France;Bière de Garde / de Mars;Chant Du Loup;Fresh from the lagering tank at the brewery
column3: and then bottle conditioned at home. Patrick Expert
column4: the brewer
column5: calls this a Blonde. He was very keen to practise his English
column6: so information was sometimes vaque or not completely understood. I didn't get the full ingredients for this beer
column7: but he doesn't use lager malt. He uses hallertau and spatz hops and a dried yeast. His brewery training was done somewhere around Herefordshire. He is very proud of the fact that he learned his craft in England. All the beers are lagered for a full four weeks
column8: and he only brews ten times a year - most of his output going to supermarkets or sold from the premises which can be visited after 5.30 during week-day evenings. He let me sample some of this from the tank
column9: even though he felt it was still green and needed another week to fully mature. There wasn't a huge difference to what I'm now drinking from the bottle - it was less fizzy and with a more pronounced bitterness
column10: but it had the same green apple flavour that I took at the time to signify a beer not quite ready. This is a light
column11: refreshing brew with a crisp tartness. Fresh
column12: delicate and very tasty. I'm not familiar with the style
column13: so I'll term it a Blonde as the brewer does.

column3: United States;Malt Liquor;Dogfish Head Brewery;"I know it is stupid... but this is one of my long time whales... Tiklmelmo hooked me up with 2!! Jason is a stellar trader for sure... This is from the 2nd release in 2010. This has been in my fridge since I received it... I cracked it to share with my brother and a work buddy who claims to be a ""Malt Licka"" aficionado.. This was the best of the bunch. Pours clear dark gold on initial pours... but later they were sorta hazy golden... no lacing... short lasting white head. Nose is clean maltiness... something that I guess is corn... smells like some bigger micro cream ales I’ve had over the years.... Flavor has a very lite splash of citrus/lighter floral hops that let you know this is not your every day drunk punch... pale malts and some corny goodness (i think) .... some booze for sure just to brand the style into your brain. Again.. the body and carbonation are akin to a bigger cream ale... medium with a lite yet frothy carbonation.. definitely interesting."

Aromas of floral and earthy hops with a fair amount of bready pilsner maltiness and a light touch of fruit and corn. The flavor is clean bready with a touch of honey and corn on the malt side with a solid shot of earthy hop flavor. Light hop bitterness is present but doesn’t let this on skew from the malty side. Light to medium body with a moderate level of carbonation and a sweet sugar watery mouthfeel. Solid cream ale

column3: United States;Dark Lager - Dunkel / Tmavý;Fox River Brewing Company;I’m honored to be the 2nd rater to drink this beer behind the infamous Slikwily. By the way

column7: Grapefruity. Very interesting first taste combination. Very intriquing indeed. Dark obsidian color and very very citrusy. Not exactly what I was expecting from a Dunkel. Very interesting beer!!! There is also a very acidic attachment to this beer as I’m drinking it. Not exactly what a dunkel should taste like. The last time I tasted anything like this was at belgianfest and it was a flemish sour. Unusual taste for this category. Thanks Slikwily for the beer!!! I'm sure it was a bad bottle and at some point to review this beer again based upon the rating of Slikwily.

Canada;Pale Lager - North Am. / Light;Molson Brewing Company (Molson Coors);It has a light golden color with good clarity and carbonation. This is topped off with a tall white head of foam that quickly settles down to a wispy thin film layer which make some slick spotty lacing on the glass. Smell: As I had expected it has a light aroma with a pale biscuity malt and very faint grassy hops. Taste/Palate: The base is a pale malt with a plain biscuity and saltine cracker like character. It has a dry overall taste with very light hop flavor and bitterness. The palate has a smooth almost creamy texture with soft carbonation.

Canada;Pale Lager - North Am. / Light;Molson Brewing Company (Molson Coors);"The only time I drank this was back when they had the bullseye on the can to encourage you ""shotgun"" the cold shot (before they had to take it off because some c**t with a long face complained it encouraged excessive consumption). It was 08:00 hours. At an employee golf tournament. An 8am shotgun start of course meant an 8am shotgun beer start for my buddy and I. The day went sharply downhill from there as we shotgunned one per hole on a 9 hole course with free shot/sampling stations between each one. The day ended by him spilling beer on my crotch while driving the golf cart then me pouring mine on his because I thought he did it on purpose. All in all it was a pretty great day except that this beer tasted like the bathroom at a Mexican bar smells like."

column19: bitterish grassy and herbal hops in the finish. Very well balanced and tasty. I remember the mystery surrounding the origins of this beer; originally
column20: it was claimed to be made at the premises but no one had ever seen the actual brewery. I personally think it has been brewed at more than one brewery throughout the years - in fact

column2: France;Bière de Garde / de Mars;Chant Du Loup;Bottled. There beer as actually a chestnut colour but you would know that for a few days
column3: as the things is absolutely loaded with CO2. Upon opening the beer preceded to gush for a day. The head lasted two! Astringent flavours pushed me back in my attempt to sample this one objectively and thoroughly. My warmest thanks though go to SilkT and Chrissie for bring this home from France for me. Cheers guys.

column2: France;Bière de Garde / de Mars;Chant Du Loup;"I had this straight from the lagering tank at the brewery and it transformed my ideas about lager. The beer came out with a huge white head - or at least it looked like a head. I had waited for a while for the head to subside
column3: but it hadn't
column4: and Patrick
column5: the brewer
column6: was obviously waiting for me to try it and tell him what I thought. I intended to drink through the head
column7: but when I put my lips to the glass and tipped it back I soon realised that the huge creamy white head was in fact the beer itself. And Wow! It was soft and delicious
column8: full of honey and toffee flavours. I asked about the malt used
column9: and after a struggle with his English Patrick told me he used caramel malt. The beer was certainly full
column10: well rounded and tasted of creamy toffee and vanilla ice-cream. It was
column12: superb. I bought a couple of bottles
column13: and I've just opened one. Hmmm. This has an insistent carbonation that I find unpleasant. It's a natural carbonation because Patrick insisted that he does nothing to the beers
column14: simply filling the bottles straight from the lagering tank. It also has an unpleasantly light body - compared to the full creamy body of the stuff straight from the tank. There is also an acidity and sourness here that doesn't taste off
column15: but is simply not enjoyable. Somewhere in this bottle is the beer I drank at the brewery - but I'm damned if I can find it! Score for direct from the tank: 4.5; score from the bottle: 2.9. Perhaps lager
column17: should always be served damned fresh!"

column3: United States;Wheat Ale;Southern Tier Brewing Company (ABV);"From Jun 2008 I got this bottle in a trade with jwc215. Thanks Joe! column4: this could be good... The taste follows the nose alright. A very tasty lemon hoppy flavour balanced by an ample malty sweetness and some wheat notes. Man
column5: I could drink a lot of this one. It's so tasty and so smooth. Very good mouthfeel here and the carbonation is actually on the light side and that works perfectly. The finish has a nice lemon bitter subtleness to it. I like! A great drinking experience and a real authentic session brew. I'm so pleased I got to try this; I don't think I've had a better example of style. Southern Tier has done it again!"

column3: United States;Stout - Imperial;Brown's Brewing Company;Seems like every craft brewery is releasing their own ultra-rare imperial stout these days. A lot of people hate this trend
column4: but I’m okay with it since
column5: more often than not
column6: these beers are really good and a great example of what American craft brewers can do regardless of size. The best example of that is Brown’s Imperial Stout
column7: made in my hometown area of New York’s Capital District. They bottled this for the first time in 2012 and limited it to only 84 total bottles (and they were only $6 each - what a bargain!). While not the best imperial stout I’ve ever had
column8: it’s still quite impressive considering it was only made with a few malts and one hop. I poured a 22oz bottle into an official Brown’s tumbler. Appearance: By far THE darkest beer I’ve ever seen! Liquid is as black as a black hole and it forms a huge
column10: almost black foamy head. The lacing and retention on this beer is fantastic. Smell: The usual imperial stout aroma of black licorice
column13: and a touch of grain alcohol. Taste: Because Brown’s Imperial Stout pours such a thick
column15: that initial taste of that initial swig is quite bitter. It’s a dry bitterness of roasted coffee and dark chocolate. Once the liquid passes the tongue it’s a whole new ballgame. Strong sweet notes of black cherry and plum with slight black licorice as it transitions to the finish. The final third of the palate is similar to the opening with the bittersweet flavors of dark chocolate
column16: French roast coffee and just a touch of alcohol. It’s like a rum without the spice or a clear liquor with a touch of cinnamon. That’s not to say this beer is absolutely delicious. There seems to be a noticeable lack of roasted malt and the sweet elements seem a little cloying. That being said
column17: the balance of the palate overall is impressive as the sweet side never becomes sickly sweet and the bitter side never becomes too dry. Drinkability: The bottle indicates the beer is 10.4% ABV
column18: but the brewer’s website says 10.2%. So either way
column19: you can tell Brown’s Imperial Stout is a pretty hefty beer. But unlike most double-digit ABV stouts
column20: there is little to no alcohol presence here. Only the faintest hint of alcohol warmth
column21: which is fine because it blends well with the natural tastes of the beer. The mouthfeel is fairly thick
column22: but extremely soft. One of the most comfortable beers I’ve ever had
column23: actually. The aftertaste is a tad dry and somewhat sticky
column24: but easily tolerable. This would be an ideal pairing with dark
column25: gamey meats or drank alone as a dessert.

column4: and there is a nice amount of it. There is also some nice chocolate and carmel/toffee elements to go along with it. Could be a bit more powerful overall. T - Starts of with a really deep chocolate malt taste that really builds nicely. Then a bit of toffee sweetness and a bit of dark fruit flavor comes through. Just a hint of bitterness at the finish that lingers
column5: from a mixture of chocolate and hops. M - Full bodied with a very low amount of carbonation. Super creamy and pretty smooth
column6: D - Fairly drinkable. It is a fairly heavy beer

column3: United States;Stout - Milk / Sweet;Brew It Up!;This draft brew from the brewery poured a small sized head of foamy finely sized tan colored bubbles that were long lasting and left behind a opaque no visible carbonation black colored body and an excellent lacing. The aroma was brown malt bready and dark malt. The mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start and at the finish. The flavor contained notes of roasted malt breads and herseys cocoa chocolate. A decent one that I would consider buying again.

More like a poorly made Amber Ale than an ESB. Another shitty beer from Davidson Brothers

column3: United States;Bitter - Premium / Strong / ESB;Davidson Brothers Restaurant and Brewery;A - Pours a rich amber-red color with a finger of off-white head atop. The head fades down to a thin ring around the glass leaving behind some lacing in the process. S - Aroma is a mix of sweet caramel malts and some fruity aromas (cherry and apple). There is also some hops and some spices in the background. T - Starts off with a mix of some sweet caramel malt and some light sweet fruit flavors. Though the middle some citrus hops come through alongside some bitterness. The finish is a mix of caramel flavor and bit of bready malts that lingers nicely. M - Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Very smooth and crisp with a nice mix of sweet and bitterness that lingers. D - Very drinkable. The hop/malt balance is really nice and the touch of added fruity flavors mixes in well. Really smooth and feels refreshing.

column8: 17: Orange-copper body and slim off-white draught head. Lighter color than previous IPAs from this brewery. Citrusy hops in the nose from dry hopping with Cascade plus some wood and fruity malts. Crisp grapefruit and woody flavor. Medium body has a less malty texture than other Turtle IPAs. This is another great IPA from Turtle Mountain. Very stylish and my favorite to date. After sampling at least 3 separate batches

column1: Lake Louie Louies Reserve Scotch Ale;Arena
column3: United States;Scotch Ale / Wee Heavy;Lake Louie Brewing (Wisconsin Brewing Company);From Feb 2008 I got this bottle in a trade with orbitalrOx. Thanks Don. This is one of my favourite styles. :^) It pours from 12 oz bottle a hazy rusty brown with a 1 finger head of foam. It shrinks after a few minutes but there's still a fine layer(with god lacing) near the end of the session. The smell is of roasted and caramel malt along with some notes of chocolate and just a wee bit of alcohol. The taste has the caramel malt up front and gives me a nice sweet flavour. Now I get a bit of chocolate
column4: big toffee
column5: some smoke(nicely done) and some roasted malt. There's also some hops hiding in the background that I find more prevalent in the finish. Yum. The alcohol is just noticeable after the swallow but doesn't interfere with the flavour at all. The mouthfeel is medium bordering on heavy and feels silky smooth. Yum again. That toffee is really make this one very drinkable given the alcohol content. I'm really happy that I got to try this Wee Heavy as it's a darn good one!

One of the most flavorful Brown Ale’s I have had ever. Mouthfeel was good with a creamy medium body and good carbonation. With the great taste this never really got old and the only thing that might slow you down drinking these is the 6.4% alcohol.

column3: Canada;Pale Lager - North Am. / Light;Walkerville Brewing Company;bottle: I picked one of these up direct from the factory in Windsor

column1: Anderson Valley Brother David's Triple Abbey-Style Ale;Boonville
column3: United States;Tripel;Anderson Valley Brewing Company;Gifted for my birthday from Doug Theresa Aadland
column4: Brother David’s Triple is an Abbey style ale brewed by Anderson Valley Brewing Company. The aroma of toffee
column5: raisins
column7: and spices are noted as you drink. The appearance is a bronze amber with a fast dissipating white head. The alcohol content is 10%. Raisins and apricots sweeten the body. The apricot imbues amazingly with how watery the beer comes across. Toffee thickens the comprehension and gives off a cream life tone with the Trappist yeast used. Honey is noticed when you lick your chops and assists the sweet tone. Pear is easily distinguished as the finish dries. Coriander compliments the apricot aspect. Clove spices the take and glows with the finish. Demerara sugar has a different sugary feel than I’m used to. Brother David’s Triple is a beautiful Trappist ale. The water
column9: and coriander against a toffee body set this beer apart from the Belgian crowd. The honey
column11: and malted barely takes this ale to another level. After spending spending a couple months in Belgium and drinking Trappist beer at this source
column12: Brother David’s Triple hits the mark for a Trappist ale. The water quality makes this strong beer easy to drink and refreshing. Cheers. Prost. Drink for the love of beer. For more beer reviews
column13: visit and like my blog “Drink For the Love of Beer.”

column3: United States;Bock- Heller Bock / Maibock;Lake Placid Pub & Brewery;Reviewed from notes. The appearance was a slight golden yellow to copper color with a film of a white foamy head that fell off at a decent pace. Sly lace. The aroma had some malty sweet caramel/toffee tones rolling over some nuts. Light grassy hops underneath. The flavor makes a decent effort to blend the malts to the hops but mainly keeps the malts up front sticking to my taste buds fairly nice and clean. Moderate bitter sort of finish. On the palate
column4: this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fair sessionability about it. Slight sort of stickiness along my tongue
column5: but acceptable. ABV felt as projected despite being just a tad higher than normal for the style

Durée moyenne de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture huileuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût légèrement houblonné. (Rating #2443)

column3: United States;Brown Ale;St. George Brewing Company;Reviewed from notes. This was poured into a pint glass. On the palate

column1: Bitter End E.P.A.- Environmental Pale Ale;Austin
column3: United States;Pale Ale - American / APA;Bitter End Bistro & Brewery;"Tap. Okay
column4: let me start by saying that I’m not one to enjoy anything just because it’s ""organic""
column5: and I don’t go out of my way to get extra enjoyment out of anything sold by hippies or nature freaks like in Austin. And before any of y’all say that I’m from Texas and so my opinion of rabid liberals doesn’t count
column6: you ain’t been to Austin. The other day I was at a stop light
column8: and the car in front of me
column9: and the ones to its left and right ALL had anti-Bush or pro-Kerry bumper stickers. This beer was a good example of environmental stuff actually coming through. The water came from the Bitter End head brewer’s house
column10: where he has some rainwater catching and filtering system. It makes the mouthfeel something special - smooth
column11: without a bite to it. Normally when I say that a beer doesn’t have bite
column13: but this one is different. It’s ""light"" in your mouth
column14: for lack of a better word
column15: almost as if the beer is disappearing in your mouth like cotton candy. The organic hops come on strong
column16: punching through until the end. Some standard BE malts
column17: I want more of this stuff!!"

column5: hopped pale ale with peach flavor that is just right balance-- strong but not overwhelming the pale ale taste. Maybe the pits and skin give it that nice bitterness. Drink this one chilled. Frothy head. Can quench thirst but also as a sipper. Sometimes the first chilly smell and sip gives me a pleasant fleeting head rush that is hard to describe. Great change of pace. Classic lawnmowing brew. Perhaps too much carbonation. Brenan chain in Wisconsin may be only place to get it.

column1: El Toro Peach Flavored Ale;Morgan Hill

column6: along with some sugary nectarine juice with peach jolly ranchers slowly diffusing. Peaches (imagine that) emasculate the flavor as expected
column7: yet they inhibit a husky quality
column8: spiffed by a curt bitter element that’s immediately pinned to the roof of the mouth. Substantive cohabitation is completely comprised of a musky pils quality. Peaches wrapped in tamale husks and faded grass stains curtail on the coattails. The formula works

column3: United States;Pale Ale - English;Elm City Brewing Co.;This is a decent Pale Ale I just tried at my local brewpub. Not sure who or how they come up with some of their names though. This beer pours a somewhat cloudy copper body topped with a medium white foamy head. The head diminishes quickly and there’s only a little bit of lace on the glass halfway through the beer. Aroma is slightly sweet with hops and maybe a little grassy. It tasted sweet and slightly hoppy but not as hoppy as I would have liked. The finish was sweet and a little bland leaving me wanting more. It felt sort of watery but not at all a bad beer. Compared to the others I’ve had here it’s actually one of the best. A little more flavor and it would have been great!

column3: Germany;Zwickelbier/Kellerbier/Landbier;Hofbräuhaus München;Bottiglia. Il gusto al naso resta attratto dall'orzo. L'olfatto viene stimolato in maniera normale e il modo in cui permane è sufficiente. Il cappello di schiuma ha una buona tenuta. La grandezza delle bollicine è a grana fine. Il liquido appare velato e anche qui la grandezza delle bollicine è medio-fine. Il colore è giallo dorato carico. Il corpo è rotondo. L'amaro è pronunciato. La forza gustativa è normale e permane in maniera sufficiente. Le sensazioni boccali finali risultano di pronta beva. Il finale è semplice e dissetante. Il retrogusto è di media intensità. Al gusto vengono donati toni di miele

England;Apple Cider;Sheppy's Cider;this is (without doubt) the best single variety cider i have ever tasted (and i have tasted loads!) - its a real cider drinkers cider. jt has a really flavour curve that starts with a sharp apple tang - you can taste the orchard. As you swallow the flavour slowly develops to a crisp dry ever-so-slightly bitter end. i drink many ciders all the time and this is one i always come back to a and compare all others too! do yourself a favour and buy a few bottles - its tremendous! god i wish it was available on tap! christ i would die and go to heaven!! For all you Americans reading this - this is what cider should taste like! i know you guys are good at recreating flavours - RECREATE THIS ONE AND YOU WILL GET RICH! (send me a case first to check!)

column3: England;Apple Cider;Sheppy's Cider;500 ml bottle courtesy of geth_in_beer. Thanks again. (I’m only now realizing how many beer you dragged over for me). Orange-golden colour. Beautiful earthy/dusty aroma over a sweet appley aroma. Distinct apple skin tannins in the nose as well. As it warms a beautiful fragrant floral character comes from underneath the tart acidity and soft funkiness. Lightly stinky cheesy funkiness over the more normal horsey character and wild yeastiness. Some soft vanilla notes and a very dry tannic finish make this go down very easily. As it warms
column4: the sweetness comes forth a bit more
column5: but it is still very dry. Lovely cider.

column1: Rock Bottom Milwaukee American Dream IPA;Milwaukee
column3: United States;IPA;Rock Bottom Milwaukee;"It seems to me that very hoppy IPAs/APAs/DIPAs in the midwest are very citrusy or sweet
column4: while those in the west are drier and more purely bitter. If you accept this
column5: I would say that this IPA is more like a ""west coast"" IPA
column6: with a lot of hop bitterness without a lot of sweetness. It is very dry with a lot IBUs. Appearance is good...it is a rather golden IPA with a good amount of head. A lot of citrus aroma
column7: but very little citrus flavor. It is boldly bitter but without a lot of balance. For as much bitterness as this beer has
column8: I didn’t think the mouthfeel was very sticky. It was fairly drinkable. I’d order this again
column9: but I was a bit disappointed and felt that the aroma made a promise unkept by the taste."

column3: Canada;Märzen / Oktoberfest Bier;Le Cheval Blanc - Brasseur Artisan & Bar;In short: Plenty of whole-wheat cereals and plenty of woody hops. Highly drinkable amber lager. Very nice. How: Tap at brewpub. This rating for the 2008 batch The look: Almost clear pale copper body topped by a persistent small beige head In long: A ton of cereals with a whole-wheat bread flavour. A bit fluffy. A ton of hops with a fresh wet beechwood birch. Light fruity notes of citrus and gooseberries. A touch of caramel to tie it up together. Toasted but not really caramelized. An very nice overall freshness sensation. I don’t remember Cheval Blanc’s Marzen having been as good as this 2008 batch. Too bad it’s only brewed once a year because this is a beer I’d love to drink all year round. I’d be a much happier man if it was this beer that was the monthly ritual and P.M.S. the yearly affair. Life isn’t fair.

column3: Estonia;Malt Liquor;Viru Õlu (Harboe);Not produced any more. Young people used to get wasted just with 2 bottles of that brew. If you want to reproduce the taste - take any Baltic lager and add 2 shots of vodka in it. You will get 90% resemblance. All I could taste at that time was ethanol. One of the scariest beers I have ever had (there was also Saku President 10).

Estonia;Malt Liquor;Viru Õlu (Harboe);"500ml bottle @ ""Let’s drink different beers"" tasting with mate Captain at Stroomi beach in his car around october/november 2005. Star of the evening. column3: Germany;Helles / Dortmunder Export;Hasen Bräu (Hasenbräu);Bottiglia. Il gusto al naso è indirizzato verso l'orzo. L'olfatto viene stimolato in maniera normale e la maniera in cui permane è sufficiente. Il mantello birroso superiore resiste abbastanza. La grandezza delle bollicine è medio-fine. Il liquido appare trasparente. Il colore è giallo dorato brillante. Il corpo è rotondo. L'amaro è medio. La forza gustativa è normale e permane in maniera sufficiente. Le sensazioni boccali finali risultano di facile beva. Il finale è semplice e dissetante. Il retrogusto è di media intensità. Sul palato si riportano indizi di miele

England;Blonde Ale / Golden Ale;Newby Wyke Brewery;A Mes rate: Gravicask at Fin’s excellent Merton Beer Festival. Hazy yellow gold with a thin white head and yet more evidence of Fin’s hard work to keep all the beers at the festival in sparkling form. Assertive lemon sherbet hop aroma with a decent malty backbone. The flavour follows on really well. The hops are very good and give bags a fruity character. The earthy malt is adorable and it is all wrapped up in a really pleasing dry bitter finish. Straight forward English class. Jolly good.

United States;Apple Cider;Putney Mountain Winery;"Thank you jjpm74 for this experience! ;~D Very pretty blue champagne bottle. I feel guilty opening this alone. Possibly has the aroma of a strong Belgian or something really sweet. This brew has some bubbles rising in there but no head. Fusel~ness hits the olfactory immediately on the first taste. This is strong and wine like. The alcohol content is out front and knocking. You may want to think twice if you are planning to have more than 12 oz. This stuff is taste bud numbing. It is overpowering to both tongue and nose if thought of on a beer rating site. USA malt liquor brewers rejoice! Each swallow is alarming to the back of my throat. Barely any detectable carbonation. I never would consider this a drain pour
column4: but I may put it back into the bottle and reset the plastic cork. I’m going to save this for a special occasion. This is the imperial of cider. Imperial stout and imperial IPA….now we have imperial cider. This stuff is hypnotizingly brutal. Those of you who love high alky percent better go try this. Coarse
column5: very coarse; clear and coarse. I don’t think this should be rated as a beer
column8: I also believe that imp stout and ipa is a difficult to enjoy brew! . This is the stepping stone from beer to hard liquor. This is Pennsylvania state store territory. You IPA and impy stout lovers will either hate or love this cider. Kicks yer guzzi."

column6: though you can tell only lightly filtered. This one is a deep mahogany with lighter magenta and peach tints when held to the light. The head is light beige in color. Very minimal aroma
column8: highly attenuated medium malts and a fair amount of almost tannic dryness and acidity. Not overly yeasty
column9: but there is some mineral nature to it and light earthiness. Hops are leafy
column10: soily and rather diluted. Warming produces some faint chocolate sweetness
column11: but it is still stretched very lean across the grainy/toasty

column13: being rather wet in the mouth
column14: and the dryness from the nose is very present in the flavor
column16: highly attenuated and rather acidic/astringent. Some phenol extraction
column17: very light coffee or chocolate with some very minimal yeast-like mineral character on the end. Low carbonation
column18: very light body and just too much toastiness/sourdough without the necessary balancing sweetness/softness of more malt. Hops are again dry
column20: with a touch of boisterous red fruits emerging upon warming
column21: but otherwise quite muted. No alcohol present."

United States;Flavored - Other;Dragonmead Brewery;First off let me say that I am disapointed by Dragonmeads brews at the present. I have gotten the impression that with the prices of their ingredients going sky high
column4: they have cut back on the quantity of their ingredients in their brews. The end result is much weaker than usual brews. The aromas and flavors all appeared weak IMHO. With that said
column5: on to the rating. This draft brew from the brewery poured a small sized head of foamy finely sized white colored bubbles that were mostly diminishing and left behind a softly carbonated brown colored body. The almost non-existant aroma was brown malt and nutty. The mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start mediumly tingly at the finish. The mild flavor contained notes of nutty and brown malt. Not one that I would likely buy again.

column3: Canada;Flavored - Other;Brasserie Dieu du Ciel!;Un liquide mi rose mi orange. Un mousse peu abondante qui laisse tout de même de jolies dentelles sur mon verre. Un nez qui me rappelle plus une tisane à l’anis étoilé qu’une bière. Peu ou pas de céréale ni de houblons perceptibles jusqu’à présent. C’est très végétal
column4: herbacé et aromatique. Ça sent mon garde-manger. Liquide très mince et moyennement pétillant. Je suis maintenant entre la tisane et le thé vert. C’est feuillu. L’étoile de badiane occupe 99% du spectre aromatique. Je sens maintenant en bouche une céréale blanche. Du riz? Du blé? Je crois que c’est du blé
column5: mais celui-ci réclame l’anonymat. Moyennement longue en bouche
column6: cette bière manque de profondeur et de complexité certes
column7: elle est loin d’être mauvaise ou déplaisante.

column3: Canada;Flavored - Other;Brasserie Dieu du Ciel!;Une robe presque cuivrée. Un mince anneau de mousse. Un nez frais et doux de feuilles et de graines d’anis vert. Un goût franchement épicé et sec. Beaucoup d’anis mais aussi de la muscade et autres aromatiques qui partagent les mêmes molécules. Une bouche un peu mince avec une texture légèrement huileuse. Une finale plutôt sèche sur des notes herbeuses et finement poivrées. Intéressante concoction lorsque servie dans un verre de 5 onces.
Canada;Flavored - Other;Brasserie Dieu du Ciel!;Dégustée en fût à l’établissement de Montréal. De couleur orange et voilée. Nez assez épicé (anis

column7: notes de muscade et de coriandre

Belgium;Lambic - Fruited;Belle-Vue (AB InBev);"The basis for the commercial Belle-Vue fruit beers
column3: at least that is what they claim (I have a spontaneous distrust towards claims made by large industrial breweries). The pinkishly orange colour seems to give away the fact that colorants are added later in the process to arrive at Belle-Vue Kriek; aroma and taste hardly reveal any krieks at all. Fruity lambic yeastiness is present abudantly though
column4: as well as a soft lactic acidity; gentle basic character (’malse lambiek’). Contrary to the other kriekenlambics I’ve had
column5: and I’ve had them from every Belgian lambic brewery
column6: this one seems to contain only a very limited percentage of sour cherries
column7: if any at all. It was nevertheless an interesting experience gaining access to the basic lambic of the most industrial brewery of them all."

Germany;Zwickelbier/Kellerbier/Landbier;Brauerei Zehendner;Bottiglia. Il gusto al naso è indirizzato verso l'orzo. L'intensità olfattiva è normale e l'esistenza olfattiva è sufficiente. Il manto birroso superiore resiste poco. La grandezza delle bollicine è medio-fine. Il liquido è di aspetto velato e anche qui la grandezza delle bollicine è medio-fine. La carbonazione è bassa. Il colore è giallo dorato brillante. Il corpo è rotondo. L'amaro è di media potenza. La forza gustativa è normale e si prolunga in modo sufficiente. Le sensazioni boccali finali risultano di facile beva. Il finale è semplice e dissetante. Il retrogusto è di media intensità. L'aroma in bocca porta i segni di miele

However the thin body and slightly oily mouthfeel detracted from an otherwise reasonable stout.

Australia;Stout - Milk / Sweet;Braidwood Brewery;I was very worried about this beer after my experience at AIBA (all their beers tasted nasty and infected) but was pleasantly surprised. Highly carbonated which was a concern but it wasn’t infected. After letting it sit for a while
column3: the beer was an opaque black colour with a nice tight tan head. Nice chocolaty aroma with some malted milk and a hint of instant coffee. Flavour is distinctly like a cafe latte with about three sugars - not really my style but it kind of grew on me. Thin mouthfeel and the lactose is a bit of a turnoff but the roastiness just sneaks back in at the end to balance it out. I generally detest milk stouts (Mackeson’s and Sweetheart both nearly made me vomit) but this wasn’t too bad.

column1: Central City Red Racer Raspberry Wheat Ale;Surrey
column3: Canada;Flavored - Fruit;Central City Brewers + Distillers;Poured from the tap at the breweries main center in Surrey. Very good aroma of crushed raspberries. Kind of reminds me of the Mc Donalds raspberry smoothie smell. Nice refreshing taste. The carbonation keeps the taste alive and keeps the pallet tingling. I love this delivery mechanism. The beer turns into a foam that slowly released flavor without overwhelming the taste buds. I could easily have a pitcher of this on a patio with some friends.

column3: United States;Kölsch / Kölsch-Style;Wind River Brewing;I had a pint of this at my local Old Chicago: It poured a nice clear straw gold with a small head of foam that stayed for the entire session. The smell is very delicate. I note some malt sweetness and that’s about it. The taste is very delicate but there’s some malt sweetness with a touch of hop bitterness midway through that lasts through the finish. This is a really smooth beer that has just enough flavour to keep you interested and it’s quite a drinkable beer. I had it with a grilled sirloin steak.. Bottom line: I don’t have much experience with the style but this one certainly is a nice sample that is tasty and very drinkable. I think I found a new session beer! I can recommend it. 02-11-2007

column3: United States;Flavored - Fruit;Kellys Restaurant & Brewpub;Pours a cloduy yellow/brown or what you could call a dirty yellow. Nice pleasant aroma of apricot. Floral and slightly perfumey. Taste is light apricot with mild hops. Finishes crisp and clean. Nice.
United States;Flavored - Fruit;Kellys Restaurant & Brewpub;Golden-apricot color body. Big apricot aroma
column4: even when cold. Enticing
column5: but hints of concentrated apricot juice rather than the fruit itself. Refreshing apricot flavor with a decent malty underbelly. Has none of the off-flavors that are common in too many Kelly’s brews. Good.

column4: huge head
column5: big particles of yeast floating around. Aroma is fruits
column6: floral notes mild wooden notes as well as some acidic notes. Flavour is fruity
column8: a bit yeasty. Otherwise a quite nice thing.

column3: England;Bitter - Premium / Strong / ESB;White Star;BCA (from Bottles of Botley). Certainly not the worst white star beer I’ve had but not great. Smoky caramelised malt flavours with slight sourness. Just about drinkable in a masochistic kind of way.
England;Bitter - Premium / Strong / ESB;White Star;Bottle. Golden
column4: orange with floaties and an off-white foam. Aromas are caramel malts with toffee and sour fruit - I assumed it is tainted
column5: although looking at the other ratings
column6: possibly not. Flavours are sweet and sour with oranges. Fairly hoppy. Still seems tainted to me.
